chapter.title: Technical Introduction to Unix and Linux

section.title: How an Operating System works
section.para: The tasks of an operating system include management of hardwarehardware, memorymemory, processesprocesses and applicationsapplications. An operating system consists of a software kernelkernel and a number of tools, and can be considered a platformplatform for applications.
To manage the hardwarehardware, the operating system uses interruptsinterrupts and device driversdevice drivers. A monolithic kernel like Linux can dynamically load these in memory as modulesmodules.

A computer's memorymemory comes in different speeds and prices, the faster, the more expensive. Ordered from fastest to slowest we have: registersregisters inside the CPU, cachecache on the CPU, RAM modulesRAM modules and hard diskshard disks. An operating system may start pagingpaging and can use parts of the hard disk as memory storage.

A processprocess is compiled source code that is currently running on the computer. Only one process at a time can run on a CPUCPU or processor. The operating system will provide multitaskingmultitasking features by giving every process a small amount of time (about 50ms max) to run on the CPU, before interrupting it, and giving control to the next process. For us humans, applications seem to run at the same time. When more than one CPU is present in the system, the operating system can support multiprocessingmultiprocessing. This really enables applications to run simultaneously.
Applications receive a vast amount of virtual address spacevirtual address space from the operating system, so they don't interfere with other applications.

section.title: Manual Pages
section.para: Most Unix tools and commands have pretty good man pages. Type manman followed by a command (for which you want help) and start reading. Ah, and press q to quit the manpage.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man whois Reformatting whois(1), please wait... paul@laika:~$
section.para: Manpages can be useful when you are switching a lot between different flavors of unix, to find those little differences in commands. Very often manpages also describe configuration files and daemons.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man syslog.conf Reformatting syslog.conf(5), please wait... paul@laika:~$ man syslogd Reformatting syslogd(8), please wait...
section.para: The man -kman -k command (same as aproposapropos) will show you a list of manpages containing your searchstring.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man -k syslog lm-syslog-setup (8) - configure laptop mode to switch syslog.conf ... logger (1) - a shell command interface to the syslog(3) ... syslog-facility (8) - Setup and remove LOCALx facility for sysklogd syslog.conf (5) - syslogd(8) configuration file syslogd (8) - Linux system logging utilities. syslogd-listfiles (8) - list system logfiles paul@laika:~$
section.para: By now you will have noticed the numbers between the round brackets. man manman man will explain to you that these are section numbers. If you want to know more, RTFM (Read The Fantastic Manual). Unfortunately, manual pages do not have the answer to everyhting...
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man woman No manual entry for woman

section.title: Red Hat Manuals online
section.para: Red Hat has a lot of info online at http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/ in both pdf and html format. Unfortunately, the information there is not always up to date.

section.title: Searching the internet with Google
section.para: Google is a powerful tool to find help about Unix, or anything else. Here are some tricks.
Look for phrases instead of single words.
Search only pages from Belgium (or substitute .be for any other Top Level Domain).
Search for pages inside one domain
Search for pages not containing some words.

section.title: Wikipedia
section.para: Wikipedia is a web-based, free-content encyclopedia. Its growth the past two years has been astonishing. You have a good chance of finding a clear explanation by typing your search term behind http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ like this example shows.

section.title: The Linux Documentation Project
section.para: On www.tldp.orghttp://www.tldp.org you will find a lot of documentation, faqs, howtos and man pages about Linux and many other programs running on Linux.
